description.narrative:
The Fair Finance Asia Program (FFA) envisages to reduce the negative impact of national and cross-border bank investments in Asia on human rights, the environment and climate change, and to increase adequate financial services for pro-poor, inclusive economic development. The goal is to establish a sustainable financial sector in Asia, with financial sector institutions operating at national and regional level being more transparent and accountable and adhering to Economic, Social and Governance (ESG)-criteria. FFA is funded by Sida.
This project is implemented by IDEALS, the lead organization for FFA in the Philippines. It aims to contribute to the FFA-goals by undertaking in-depth research of top local banks and top 5 foreign banks to ascertain the extent of their investments, their role of underwriting the shares and bonds of companies and the collaboration with foreign financing to bankroll companies withstakes in agribusiness, mining, power generation, and climate change. Special attention will be given to bad practices that are falling into the cracks of the regulatory system (especially in relation to extractives and agribusinesses) and to state banks on theircapacity to adopt sustainable finance in their lending policies, as well as to scrutinize the impact of its financing to the said thematic areas. The result of the research will be vetted with CSOs and various industry groups to increase awareness on the issues and concerns of the financial sector that affect the poor. The result of theresearch will also feed into the efforts around buildinga grading system for ESG compliance which could be viewed through a website.

participating-org.narrative: IDEALS, Inc., Initiatives for Dialogue and Empowerment through Alternative Legal Services, Inc., is a legal-focused advocacy and service NGO organized to address the legal and technical needs of the marginalized and vulnerable groups, particularly: banana farmerswho agrarian reform beneficiaries (ARBs), victims of human rights violations, and persons <(>&<)> communities affected by natural and manmade disasters. IDEALS engages in policy advocacy and influencing work, case build-up and documentation for victims of human rights violations, and conducts legal missions to help identified marginalized and vulnerable groups establish their legal identity and/or update their records. Specifically for the work with banana farmers, IDEALS sits as part of the technicalworking group on the bill which aims to regulate the contracts and relations between the farmers and the PS. IDEALS also engages the general public for awareness-raising about the struggles of farmers locked into unfair contracts and influencing PS towards responsible and inclusive business practices and operations.
Initiative for Dialogue and Empower Through Alternative Legal Services

description.narrative: Improved policies Governments and global actors: # cases (sub)national governments or global actors adopting and/or implementing improved gender sensitive policies on promotion of a transparent, accountable and inclusive financial sector.
cases (sub)national governments or global actors adopting and/or implementing improved gender sensitive policies on promotion of a transparent, accountable and inclusive financial sector -DD2

comment.narrative:
The following are in the midyear report: 1) SEC Memo Circular on Beneficial Ownership 2) SEC Notice to formulate a comprehensive and risk-based Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Prevention Program (MTPP) 3) Sustainable finance framework circular no 1128 - BSP released the second phase of its sustainable finance framework through Circular No. 1128, which approved the guidelines governing the integration of environmental and social (E&S) risks in enterprise-wide risk management frameworks of banks. This is discussed under 2.1.a new and improved policies of the narrative report. 4) Revised guidelines on the imposition of monetary penalties for FIs and outlined the rules on filnes for transactional violations among lenders and officials 5)BSP circular 1129 - provides guidelines for corporate governance and compliance framework
The following are listed in the narrative report under 2.2a 6) BSP Memorandum instructing FIs to refrain from discriminatory practices reported in 2.2a of the narrative report 7) BSP Memorandum instructing FIs to comply on the Financial Consumer Protection Framework reported in 2.2a of the narrative report 8) SEC Notice to accomplish Anti-Money Laundering/Combating the Financing of Terrorism Inherent Risk Assessment Data Form reported in 2.2a of the narrative report.

description.narrative: pieces of evidence (documents, studies, videos, testimonies etc.) produced by Oxfam Novib and partners to support monitoring of practices and implementation of policies by the private sector

comment.narrative:
From the midyear report: 1) Kaliwa Dam Case Study, 2) Green New Deal Paper, 3) Riceland Conversion Case Study. All 3 were originally 2020 deliverables that were delayed due to travel and fieldwork resetrictions because of COVID-19 that made primary research and access to data even more difficult. NGO Forum also finished a paper on decomissioning the Masinloc Coal-Fired powerplant. However, since it is not yet publicly available it was not counted.
4) The ANGOC Agricredit Study was completed and launched last December 6 2021. The research was also shared with FF ET. This is discussed under 2.1.b new case studies. 5) The Gender Case Study was completed last December 2021. The paper is undergoing revisions for layouting and development of comms materials.

description.narrative: public events/spaces organised by Oxfam Novib and partners in which citizens express their needs and aspirations to policy makers.

comment.narrative: Communications materials enumerated here for year 2021 are materials for: Riceland Conversion campaign, the Sustainability reporting seminar, Defund Jalaur Dam Campaign, Kaliwa Dam Case Study, International Women’s Day campaign in tandem with GRAISEA, Promotional material for the Interpreting Financial Institutions’ Annual and Sustainability reports seminar, COP26 and climate change in the Philippine context, the Agri-Agra Law, Free Prior and Informed Consent (FPIC), and shared campaigns with the Fossil Banks platform, Protect our Lands, and NGO Forum’s #FossilFreeADB Campaign.

comment.narrative: The CSOs that attended trainings for the coalition and allies are: 1) IDEALS, 2) ANGOC, 3) FDC, 4) NGO Forum on the ADB 5) Bukluran, 6) FSSI, 7) Oxfam Philippines, 7) Bantay Kita, 8) Philippine Movement for Climate Justice - PMCJ, 9) Philippine Daily Inquirer, and 10) Spark Philippines.

comment.narrative:
1. Collaboration with Bukluran for an investigative story following the CIJ story-based investigative journalism training.
The following were listed in the midyear report: 2. Short joint online campaign against Kaliwa Dam with the Protect Our Land student advocacy group 3. FFP joins the Fossil Banks No Thanks platform by BankTrack
